text: hi everyone welcome to IGCSE study buddy

in this video you are going to learn
part 2 of chapter 17 inheritance
before we begin this section there are
some important definitions you must
learn
so we already learned that inheritance
is the transmission of genetic
information from generation to
generation
a gene is a section of DNA that provides
instructions for making a specific
protein which influences a particular
characteristic
alleles are variations of the same gene
since we possess two copies of each
chromosome we also have two copies of
each gene resulting in two alleles for
each gene these alleles come from our
mother and father which means they may
not carry the same information
for instance when considering the gene
responsible for eye color an individual
could have one allele for brown eyes and
another allele for blue eyes
genotype refers to the genetic makeup of
an organism including all of its genes
and alleles it represents the
combination of inherited genes that
determine an organism's characteristics
phenotype is the observable features of
an organism so it can be a feature that
we can see like eye or hair color or it
can be a feature that we can find like
blood type
[Music]
homozygous is having two identical
alleles of a particular Gene
two identical homozygous individuals
that breed together will be pure
breeding
heterozygous is having two different
alleles of a particular Gene
a heterozygous individual will not be
pure breeding
so for example say we are talking about
a gene with the alleles capital A and
simple a
the homozygous genotypes will be either
capital a capital A or simple a simple a
so homozygous means having two identical
alleles
the heterozygous genotype will be
capital a simple a heterozygous means
having two different alleles we normally
write the capital letter or the dominant
allele first
alleles can be dominant or recessive a
dominant allele is an allele that is
expressed if it is present in the
genotype
a dominant allele only requires one
parent to pass it on for the trait to be
visible in the physical appearance that
is the phenotype
a recessive allele is an allele that is
only expressed when there is no dominant
allele of the gene present in the
genotype
so a recessive allele needs to be
inherited from both parents for the
trait to be visible in the phenotype
if there is only one recessive allele
present it will remain hidden and the
dominant trait will be expressed
dominant alleles are represented by
capital letters while recessive alleles
are represented by the same letter in
lower case
monohybrid inheritance is the study of
how a single trait or characteristic is
passed from parents to their offspring
upon a square is a helpful tool to
determine the possible combinations of
alleles in Offspring it allows us to
calculate the ratio of these
combinations remember in a Punnett
Square dominant alleles are represented
by capital letters while recessive
alleles are represented by the same
letter in lower case
for example the human eye color is
controlled by a gene that has alleles
one allele for this Gene May code for
brown eyes whereas another allele May
code for blue eyes
say the brown eye allele is dominant and
is shown as capital B
the blue eye allele is recessive and is
shown as simple B if a question doesn't
specify the letters for alleles you can
choose any letter to represent them just
make sure to use the same letters
consistently in your discussion and
avoid using letters that look similar in
their capital and lowercase forms for
example like Capital C and simple C
so the homozygous dominant genotype for
brown eyes will be capital b capital B
and the homozygous recessive genotype
for blue eyes will be simple B simple B
in the first example Let's cross a PO
braiding brown eyed parent that is
homozygous dominant capital b capital B
with a PO braiding blue eyed parent or
homozygous recessive simple B simple B
so remember the term pure breeding
indicates that the individual is
homozygous for that characteristic
to make a Panna Square put one parent's
alleles on the top row and the other
parents alleles on the left column
the cells in the Square will show the
different combinations of alleles from
each parent the results you get in the
Square will be The Offspring the babies
so the genotype of the PO breeding brown
eyed parent will be capital b capital B
and the genotype of the pure breeding
blue eyed parent will be simple B simple
B
the gametes will be capital B and
capital B for the pure breeding brown
eyed parent
and for the pure breeding blue-eyed
parent it will be simple B and simple B
so now we cross them each cell
represents a potential of Spring's

will look like this
here we will have capital B simple B so
The Offspring will have brown eyes but
this genotype is heterozygous
here we will have capital B simple b as
well
here we will have capital B simple B
and also here we will have capital B
simple B
by completing a Panet Square You can
predict the probability of various
outcomes in monohybrid crosses
so as you can see there's a 100 chance
that all The Offspring will have brown
eyes
when it comes to eye color having just
one copy of the brown eye allele capital
B is enough to show brown eyes because
it is dominant over the blue eye allele
simple B so if a parent with po brown

a parent with pure blue eyes simple B
simple B all the children will inherit

brown eye parent

offspring
here we will have capital B simple b a

B

A homozygous blue eyed offspring

in the next example let's say a

in this cross there is a one is to one

now let's learn how to use a test cross
to identify an unknown genotype
so for example let's say we are studying
a person with brown eyes of unknown
genotype how can we determine whether
the person is homozygous dominant that
is capital b capital b or heterozygous
that is capital B simple B for the brown
eye color trait
so what we know is that the brown eyed
person may be either homozygous dominant
that is have the genotype capital b
capital B
or heterozygous that is capital B simple
B
to determine the genotype of an
individual with an unknown eye color you
can cross them with someone who has blue
eyes which represents the recessive

on the other hand let's assume that the

this Gene so the genotype of the

simple B

having blue eyes
if any of The Offspring have blue eyes
it would confirm that the person is
heterozygous that is capital B simple B
because the presence of the recessive
allele simple B would result in the

you have to be able to understand
pedigree diagrams for the inheritance of
a given characteristic
pedigree diagrams are used to track how
a specific trait or disease is passed
through generations in a family
they can help predict the chances of
inheriting the genetic disorder
in a pedigree diagram males are shown as
Square shapes while females are shown as
circles
affected individuals are shown in red
while unaffected ones are shown in blue
horizontal lines connecting males and
females show that they have Offspring
which are displayed beneath each couple
co-dominance is a situation in which
both alleles in heterozygous organisms
contribute to the phenotype
inheritance of blood group is an example
of codominance
in the inheritance of blood groups there
are three alleles for the gene I a ib
and I O
these three possible alleles can give us
the following genotypes and phenotypes
the alleles I a and IB for the blood
group Gene are co-dominant meaning that
they both show their effects when
present together
they are both dominant over the i o
allele
the gene is represented by the letter I
and the superscripts a b and O represent
the different alleles
let's look at a genetic diagram to
predict the outcome of a cross that
involves codominant alleles
so for example say we are asked to show
how a parent with blood group a and a
parent with blood group B can produce
Offspring with blood group O
so the genotype for the parent with
blood group a will be i a i o
and for the parent with blood group b it
will be i b i o
the gametes will be I a and I O for one
parent and IB and I O for the other we
know that these are only their genotypes
and not i a i a or i b i b because
according to the example we know that
they are able to produce a child with
blood group O and so the child must have
inherited an allele for group O from
each parent also remember to write the
genotype with the dominant letters first
so now we cross them here we will have i
a i b which is an offspring with the
blood group a b
here we will have i a i o which is blood
group a
here we will have ibio which is blood
group b
and here we will have i o i o which is
an offspring with the blood group O
so as you can see there's a 1 in 4 or 25
percent chance of a child with blood
group O
there's also a 25 chance of producing a
child with blood group a b a 25 chance
of producing a child with blood group a
and a 25 chance of producing a child
with blood group b
finally let's learn about sex linkage
a sex-linked characteristic is a feature
in which the gene responsible is located
on a sex chromosome and this makes the
characteristic more common in 1 6 than
in the other
red green color blindness is an example
of six linkage it is a genetic condition
that is caused by a mutation in the
genes located on the X chromosome
let's use a genetic diagram to predict
the results of a cross involving
six-linkage
in this example we'll consider a cross
between a normal male and a carrier
female where x capital r represents the
normal allele
and X simple R represents the color
blind allele
so the genotype for the normal father
will be x capital r y
and for the carrier mother it will be x
capital r x simple r
the gametes will be x capital r and Y
for the father
and for the mother it will be x capital
r and X simple r
so in the carrier mother's genotype the
dominant allele masks the effect of the
recessive allele so even though she
doesn't have the disease she has a 50
chance of passing it on to her Offspring
please make sure to put X chromosomes
before Y and you also write any six
chromosomes with the dominant letters
first so now we cross them the Panna
Square will look like this
here we will have x capital r x capital
r which is a normal female
here we will have x capital r x simple R
which is a carrier female female because
x x right
here we will have x capital r y which is
a normal male
and here we will have X simple R Y which
is a color blind male
so as you can see there is a 1 in 4 or
25 percent chance of a male child with
color blindness
there's also a 25 chance of producing a
normal female a 25 chance of producing a
carrier female and a 25 chance of
producing a normal male
the inheritance of red green color
blindness is more commonly seen in males
as they only have one X chromosome
females on the other hand need to
inherit two copies of the color blind
allele that is X simple r x simple R to
exhibit color blindness as the normal
dominant allele x capital r on their
other X chromosome masks the effect of
the recessive allele
